comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I think it is 1 shilling and 4 pence,  same price as Home & Colonial 'Best' Tea on 10 May 1910, the following Tuesday -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/5727931586/]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: You can see a man sitting on the second step of a plinth at left, beside the Lipton's board. Probably the square yoke at the centre of this OS 25" map view.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: My wifes family came from just off to the left of this shot off the Yellow Road.  The cattle fair took place there right into the '60's and her younger brother loved going there when down on holidays.  He invariably came home covered in cow dung as he was very small and got slapped by many a cows tail as he wandered about.  This is a great shot, full of life and action, what a great way to start the weekend!  The men sitting behind the stand are on the steps of the Bullpost which is still there in Ballybricken.  You can just see the top of the post above the van.

comment.author: 56105315@N07
comment._content: A wonderful image.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Is there some image editing going on around the W in Waterford, it looks like the shafts of the carriage originally obscured the W and that the top of both shafts were removed and the W retouched in white.

Have I seen that cow in another photo?

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] No Danny, that's her first cousin twice removed visiting from Kilkenny;-0

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: A wonderful photo of a very familiar place, I played all around there as a child and remember the cattle market and Bullpost very well. This is another view of Ballybricken, I think the original may be in the NLI collection

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: This is a Pathe newsreel from 1926 showing Captain W. A. Redmond addressing a meeting in Ballybricken.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] It is indeed - this is it. Paul, I'm wondering about your bacon curing chimney note above. One of our Facebook people, Niall Ahearne, suggested that the chimney "was from the old Strangman's Brewery in Mary Street, later to become Cherry's Brewery and now part of Diageo." What do you think?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]That is possible, its a little difficult to tell from the photo, but Denny's original factory was in Penrose lane which is pretty close to where the chimney looks to be in the photo, then again the brewery is not too far from there either. The other chimney possibly belongs to Mattersons Bacon factory.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: This is a closer view of Strangmans and their chimney in the NLI collection.

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: Thanks for posting this. By doing so you are ensuring that the real history of Ireland and it's people is made known to the world. This is the history as it should be taught and these photographs are windows into a past that would otherwise be forgotten - history as seen through the eyes of ordinary people. And I'll bet the milk tasted better than the stuff we get today!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56225952@N06] And if the proprietors of the Waterford Tea & Coffee Van ran short of milk, they could just head out with the beautiful jug in search of a passing cow...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content:
I certainly believe that the chimney is on Strangman's brewery. The Denny's factory chimney would have been to the left of the tea and coffee van  as the factory was in Morgan Street/Military Road. I think that the Poole collection may have a photo of a new boiler being installed at the brewery which could have been contemporaneous with the chimney.

 Captain Redmond was elected in Waterford after the death of his father John Redmond (in 1918) who had represented Waterford in the British parliament since 1891. William was subsequently elected to the Dail to represent Waterford. He had the DSO from military service in the 1914/18 war I believe, so he would have had a unique collection of letters after his name. William Redmond, MP, TD, DSO. When Capt William Redmond died , his wife was elected to the Dail as a TD in his place, so we had a Redmond representing Waterford from 1891 until Mrs Redmond died in 1952.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04/] In later years Dennys was on Morgan street but their original premises were near Penrose Lane. The factory in Morgan sreet was originally J.J. Richardsons Queens Bacon Factory, I think you are right about the chimney being Strangmans though, looking at the old maps I don't think the Penrose lane factory chimney would have been visible from this part of Ballybricken. There is an illustration of J.J. Richardsons factory on page 378 of Egans Guide to Waterford, a copy of it on PDF can be downloaded here Egans Guide to Waterford

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content:
Ofarri,
 I think the Penrose Lane chimney is visible in the space to the right of the Tea and Coffee van sign. Was Matterson's bacon factory where the Forum is in the Glen. I thought i read somewhere that the actual bacon factory was converted into the Regal cinema which was the Forum theatre's predecessor?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Desmond I think the Penrose lane Chimney would have been to the right of the one we think is Strangmans and probably obscured by the buildings on the right,. I commented earlier that the other chimney might be Mattersons, it looks to be in the right location, and yes you are right the Regal was later built on the site.
